segment.source: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed into it for the purpose of privacy.
segment.target: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed into it for the purpose of privacy.

segment.source: Guidelines for password boxes
segment.target: Guidelines for password boxes

segment.source: Password box
segment.target: Password box

segment.source: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed into it for the purpose of privacy.
segment.target: A password box is a text input box that conceals the characters typed into it for the purpose of privacy.

segment.source: A password box looks like a text box, except that it renders placeholder characters in place of the text that has been entered.
segment.target: A password box looks like a text box, except that it renders placeholder characters in place of the text that has been entered.

segment.source: You can configure the placeholder character.
segment.target: You can configure the placeholder character.

segment.source: By default, the password box provides a way for the user to view their password by holding down a reveal button.
segment.target: By default, the password box provides a way for the user to view their password by holding down a reveal button.

segment.source: You can disable the reveal button, or provide an alternate mechanism to reveal the password, such as a check box.
segment.target: You can disable the reveal button, or provide an alternate mechanism to reveal the password, such as a check box.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.target: PasswordBox class

segment.target: Password property

segment.target: PasswordChar property

segment.target: PasswordRevealMode property

segment.target: PasswordChanged event

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Use a PasswordBox control to collect a password or other private data, such as a Social Security number.
segment.target: Use a PasswordBox control to collect a password or other private data, such as a Social Security number.

segment.source: For more info about choosing the right text control, see the Text controls article.
segment.target: For more info about choosing the right text control, see the Text controls article.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: The password box has several states, including these notable ones.
segment.target: The password box has several states, including these notable ones.

segment.source: A password box at rest can show hint text so that the user knows its purpose:
segment.target: A password box at rest can show hint text so that the user knows its purpose:

segment.target: Password box in rest state with hint text

segment.source: When the user types in a password box, the default behavior is to show bullets that hide the text being entered:
segment.target: When the user types in a password box, the default behavior is to show bullets that hide the text being entered:

segment.target: Password box focus state typing text

segment.source: Pressing the "reveal" button on the right gives a peek at the password text being entered:
segment.target: Pressing the "reveal" button on the right gives a peek at the password text being entered:

segment.target: Password box text revealed

segment.source: Create a password box
segment.target: Create a password box

segment.source: Use the Password property to get or set the contents of the PasswordBox.
segment.target: Use the Password property to get or set the contents of the PasswordBox.

segment.source: You can do this in the handler for the PasswordChanged event to perform validation while the user enters the password.
segment.target: You can do this in the handler for the PasswordChanged event to perform validation while the user enters the password.

segment.source: Or, you can use another event, like a button Click, to perform validation after the user completes the text entry.
segment.target: Or, you can use another event, like a button Click, to perform validation after the user completes the text entry.

segment.source: Here's the XAML for a password box control that demonstrates the default look of the PasswordBox.
segment.target: Here's the XAML for a password box control that demonstrates the default look of the PasswordBox.

segment.source: When the user enters a password, you check to see if it's the literal value, "Password".
segment.target: When the user enters a password, you check to see if it's the literal value, "Password".

segment.source: If it is, you display a message to the user.
segment.target: If it is, you display a message to the user.

segment.source: Here's the result when this code runs and the user enters "Password".
segment.target: Here's the result when this code runs and the user enters "Password".

segment.source: Password box with a validation message
segment.target: Password box with a validation message

segment.source: Password character
segment.target: Password character

segment.source: You can change the character used to mask the password by setting the PasswordChar property.
segment.target: You can change the character used to mask the password by setting the PasswordChar property.

segment.source: Here, the default bullet is replaced with an asterisk.
segment.target: Here, the default bullet is replaced with an asterisk.

segment.source: The result looks like this.
segment.target: The result looks like this.

segment.source: Password box with a custom character
segment.target: Password box with a custom character

segment.source: Headers and placeholder text
segment.target: Headers and placeholder text

segment.source: You can use the Header and PlaceholderText properties to provide context for the PasswordBox.
segment.target: You can use the Header and PlaceholderText properties to provide context for the PasswordBox.

segment.source: This is especially useful when you have multiple boxes, such as on a form to change a password.
segment.target: This is especially useful when you have multiple boxes, such as on a form to change a password.

segment.source: Password box in rest state with hint text
segment.target: Password box in rest state with hint text

segment.source: Maximum length
segment.target: Maximum length

segment.source: Specify the maximum number of characters that the user can enter by setting the MaxLength property.
segment.target: Specify the maximum number of characters that the user can enter by setting the MaxLength property.

segment.source: There is no property to specify a minimum length, but you can check the password length, and perform any other validation, in your app code.
segment.target: There is no property to specify a minimum length, but you can check the password length, and perform any other validation, in your app code.

segment.source: Password reveal mode
segment.target: Password reveal mode

segment.source: The PasswordBox has a built-in button that the user can press to display the password text.
segment.target: The PasswordBox has a built-in button that the user can press to display the password text.

segment.source: Here's the result of the user's action.
segment.target: Here's the result of the user's action.

segment.source: When the user releases it, the password is automatically hidden again.
segment.target: When the user releases it, the password is automatically hidden again.

segment.source: Password box text revealed
segment.target: Password box text revealed

segment.source: Peek mode
segment.target: Peek mode

segment.source: By default, the password reveal button (or "peek" button) is shown.
segment.target: By default, the password reveal button (or "peek" button) is shown.

segment.source: The user must continuously press the button to view the password, so that a high level of security is maintained.
segment.target: The user must continuously press the button to view the password, so that a high level of security is maintained.

segment.source: The value of the PasswordRevealMode property is not the only factor that determines whether a password reveal button is visible to the user.
segment.target: The value of the PasswordRevealMode property is not the only factor that determines whether a password reveal button is visible to the user.

segment.source: Other factors include whether the control is displayed above a minimum width, whether the PasswordBox has focus, and whether the text entry field contains at least one character.
segment.target: Other factors include whether the control is displayed above a minimum width, whether the PasswordBox has focus, and whether the text entry field contains at least one character.

segment.source: The password reveal button is shown only when the PasswordBox receives focus for the first time and a character is entered.
segment.target: The password reveal button is shown only when the PasswordBox receives focus for the first time and a character is entered.

segment.source: If the PasswordBox loses focus and then regains focus, the reveal button is not shown again unless the password is cleared and character entry starts over.
segment.target: If the PasswordBox loses focus and then regains focus, the reveal button is not shown again unless the password is cleared and character entry starts over.

segment.source: CautionPrior to Windows 10, the password reveal button was not shown by default.
segment.target: CautionPrior to Windows 10, the password reveal button was not shown by default.

segment.source: If the security of your app requires that the password is always obscured, be sure to set PasswordRevealMode to Hidden.
segment.target: If the security of your app requires that the password is always obscured, be sure to set PasswordRevealMode to Hidden.

segment.source: Hidden and Visible modes
segment.target: Hidden and Visible modes

segment.source: The other PasswordRevealMode enumeration values, Hidden and Visible, hide the password reveal button and let you programmatically manage whether the password is obscured.
segment.target: The other PasswordRevealMode enumeration values, Hidden and Visible, hide the password reveal button and let you programmatically manage whether the password is obscured.

segment.source: To always obscure the password, set PasswordRevealMode to Hidden.
segment.target: To always obscure the password, set PasswordRevealMode to Hidden.

segment.source: Unless you need the password to be always obscured, you can provide a custom UI to let the user toggle the PasswordRevealMode between Hidden and Visible.
segment.target: Unless you need the password to be always obscured, you can provide a custom UI to let the user toggle the PasswordRevealMode between Hidden and Visible.

segment.source: In previous versions of Windows Phone, PasswordBox used a check box to toggle whether the password was obscured.
segment.target: In previous versions of Windows Phone, PasswordBox used a check box to toggle whether the password was obscured.

segment.source: You can create a similar UI for your app, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: You can create a similar UI for your app, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: You can also use other controls, like ToggleButton, to let the user switch modes.
segment.target: You can also use other controls, like ToggleButton, to let the user switch modes.

segment.source: This example shows how to use a CheckBox to let a user switch the reveal mode of a PasswordBox.
segment.target: This example shows how to use a CheckBox to let a user switch the reveal mode of a PasswordBox.

segment.source: This PasswordBox looks like this.
segment.target: This PasswordBox looks like this.

segment.source: Password box with a custom reveal button
segment.target: Password box with a custom reveal button

segment.source: Choose the right keyboard for your text control
segment.target: Choose the right keyboard for your text control

segment.source: To help users to enter data using the touch keyboard, or Soft Input Panel (SIP), you can set the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data the user is expected to enter.
segment.target: To help users to enter data using the touch keyboard, or Soft Input Panel (SIP), you can set the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data the user is expected to enter.

segment.source: PasswordBox supports only the Password and NumericPin input scope values.
segment.target: PasswordBox supports only the Password and NumericPin input scope values.

segment.source: Any other value is ignored.
segment.target: Any other value is ignored.

segment.source: For more info about how to use input scopes, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.
segment.target: For more info about how to use input scopes, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Use a label or placeholder text if the purpose of the password box isn't clear.
segment.target: Use a label or placeholder text if the purpose of the password box isn't clear.

segment.source: A label is visible whether or not the text input box has a value.
segment.target: A label is visible whether or not the text input box has a value.

segment.source: Placeholder text is displayed inside the text input box and disappears once a value has been entered.
segment.target: Placeholder text is displayed inside the text input box and disappears once a value has been entered.

segment.source: Give the password box an appropriate width for the range of values that can be entered.
segment.target: Give the password box an appropriate width for the range of values that can be entered.

segment.source: Word length varies between languages, so take localization into account if you want your app to be world-ready.
segment.target: Word length varies between languages, so take localization into account if you want your app to be world-ready.

segment.source: Don't put another control right next to a password input box.
segment.target: Don't put another control right next to a password input box.

segment.source: The password box has a password reveal button for users to verify the passwords they have typed, and having another control right next to it might make users accidentally reveal their passwords when they try to interact with the other control.
segment.target: The password box has a password reveal button for users to verify the passwords they have typed, and having another control right next to it might make users accidentally reveal their passwords when they try to interact with the other control.

segment.source: To prevent this from happening, put some spacing between the password in put box and the other control, or put the other control on the next line.
segment.target: To prevent this from happening, put some spacing between the password in put box and the other control, or put the other control on the next line.

segment.source: Consider presenting two password boxes for account creation: one for the new password, and a second to confirm the new password.
segment.target: Consider presenting two password boxes for account creation: one for the new password, and a second to confirm the new password.

segment.source: Only show a single password box for logins.
segment.target: Only show a single password box for logins.

segment.source: When a password box is used to enter a PIN, consider providing an instant response as soon as the last number is entered instead of using a confirmation button.
segment.target: When a password box is used to enter a PIN, consider providing an instant response as soon as the last number is entered instead of using a confirmation button.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
